entries.text: hey everyone
nick diabetis here teaching you
financial modeling today
we're going to be introducing the second
project
in the course on probabilistic loan
pricing
so this project has a couple of main
goals for your learning objectives one
is to have a model where probability
is really a first-class citizen
something that we're thinking about
very deeply within the base model itself
probability factors into so many
financial models
that it's good to hit that early in the
course
and then the other main
area we're testing here in this project
is
then to be able to um
extend the base model in different
ways so here we're going to build out
an initial model and we'll have to run
that model a bunch of times
to understand all the different ways
that things could occur
so let's talk about what this project
actually is
so the idea here is
that you're an analyst within a bank
and the bank is considering doing a loan
to a small business so
this also gets in the whole debt area
and decisions
of of lenders
so the business needs to
buy a machine they want to borrow money
to buy the machine
and then after some amount of time
they're going to repay that loan
in full the interest is paid annually
at a certain rate based off of the
amount that they borrowed
and where the probability factors into
this
is that the business is not always going
to be able to pay back the loan there is
a
chance that they're going to default on
the loan
and not be able to make their payments
um so the probability of default here
it starts at an initial probability of
default and then it decreases over time
because the business becomes
more mature year over year and so it's
less likely that they're going to
default
as each year goes by but
in that final year when the loan is
actually due the business
doesn't just have to pay the interest
payment they have to pay
the full amount of the loan the
principal in addition
to the interest payment so that's a much
bigger
obligation for that final year and so
the final year
has a separate default probability which
is going to be higher than their typical
default probability as overtime would
save for the interest payments
and we need to model in
what happens whether the borrower
defaults or doesn't default
and the borrower can default in any
given year
that they have to make a payment
so whenever the borrower defaults then
they're going to go into bankruptcy and
we're going to say that the bankruptcy
process always takes two years
and then uh after bankruptcy the
lender is going to collect a certain
percentage of the original loan amount
the recovery percentage um
and so what that means as far as forming
the cash flows
uh in the year that the borrower
defaults then there will be zero
cash flow in that year it'll be zero
cash flow
um the next year and then two years
after the default we're going to get the
recovery payment
as the lender recovery times the
price of the machine which is equal to
the loan amount
um and so that does mean that the amount
of cash flows
could be greater than the amount of the
loan if they defaulted in the last year
then
it's going to be two years more than the
life alone that the final cash flow
comes
so this is a fairly realistic kind of
model to determine basically what
what terms should the bank offer on the
loan
um and so the main question here
is uh you know you're you're the loan
analyst
trying to come up with what are the
appropriate terms
for this loan to this bank based on what
we know about the bank
um and so
you're trying to give the loan officer
all the information to make these
decisions
so you want to be able to say with your
model for any given inputs
what's the expected irr of the loan
and what does that irr look like for
some different interest rates um so
here we're going to be looking at 30 35
and 40 interest rates for the loan
um and then
it goes even further to say that
um you know there's always a lot of
uncertainty in estimating the
probability of default
you can never estimate that accurately
so
uh the lending officer wants to see what
everything looks like
with some different assumptions for
the initial probability of default so
uh base case is 20 per year
but the lending officer also wants you
to evaluate
10 percent and 30 per year
and then the other factor here
is how long should the loan be and so
the lending officer also wants to see
all the results with 5
10 and 20 years
[Music]
and important thing about how the
results should be structured
is that your model should show all of
these
results it shouldn't require going in
and manually changing around numbers to
produce these results
just when i open up the model i should
be able to see the answers for
all of these different interest rates
probabilities defaults and loan lifes
and then it's also
part of the main problem to then
visualize
your result there should be graphs and
conditional formatting here
um so a few notes and assumptions
we can add into this to make things
easier
so first is that you can assume there's
only going to be 20 years
of loan life that's the maximum loan
life
um if your model can handle more that's
great
but um i'm not going to test anything
longer than 20 years in your model
but keep in mind that that could be up
to 22 years of cash flows if the
borrower defaults in that final year
um and then as far as the general
approach to build out the model
i think it's easiest to go at this with
an internal
randomness approach um
so with the basic structure being that
you build out
the base model which um
just gets you the irr for one set of
inputs
and then you're going to um
run that base model a bunch of different
times with different
uh randomly choosing the default cases
um it is possible to do everything in
terms of expected value and not actually
have a random component
in your model but that does take a lot
of fairly complicated math
to make that happen i've only ever seen
a couple students do that
and i think it's generally a much more
difficult way to go about building
this model and it also doesn't really
hit
on a lot of the things that i'm trying
to test with this model going with the
internal randomness approach you're
going to get much more comfortable
working with a random model and being
able to extend
an existing model so that's the approach
i would recommend in general
um so when you're doing the internal
randomness approach
now you're going to be running the model
a bunch of times to
discover what the true expected irr is
for each set of inputs
each time it's picking a different
default case each time you're on the
model
so now that it's not a deterministic
model
you put the same inputs in and you're
going to get different outputs each time
so you've got to keep running it and
then you've got to take the expected
value
across the iterations to get
an actual estimate of the result
and the greater number of iterations you
use the more accurate
that answer is going to be but the
longer it's going to take to run your
model
so there is a trade-off there and what i
would recommend
is as you're building everything out
keep the number of iterations low
uh just so you can run everything
quickly and then
once you think you've got it right then
increase the number of iterations
so you can run it a couple of times and
check against
the provided answers
um so
and then when you actually submit the
final you want to run it with a thousand
iterations before you submit so you can
get your final answers in there
and if you've got an excel model or a
combination model we'll talk more on
that in a moment
then it can take a substantial amount of
time to run your model with all these
iterations
um so make sure that
you're planning for that time and not
just 11 55 pm you're done
now let me try and run this thing with a
thousand iterations oh wait it's taking
way too long

this is a big contrast from the last
project

you know build help you build a
competency

nothing way off and save your results

thousand iterations again
